newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek critics vow to stop Athens' 2004 Olympic bid.
newsitem.headline: Greek critics vow to stop Athens' 2004 Olympic bid.

text.p: A budding opposition to Athens' bid to host the 2004 summer Olympics has predicted an environmental, city planning and financial disaster if Greece wins the world's biggest sports festival.
Athens, among 11 cities vying for the Games, has prided itself on enjoying widespread public support and being spared the local opposition dogging other candidates.
But the newly founded Citizens Initiative Against Hosting the 2004 Olympics in Athens promised at a meeting late on Wednesday to change that, propounding a list of objections.
The Athens bidding committee rejected the claims on Thursday, saying they were unfounded.
The opposition group includes representatives of areas where major Games-related construction is planned, various professional unions and private citizens opposing the Games.

"We are organising a campaign against hosting the 2004 Olympics," architect Panayotis Dotsikas told Reuters. "We are collecting signatures and we are preparing an anti-bid file, which we will submit here and abroad."

"Our anti-bid file will include facts and arguments against hosting the Olympics as well as opinions from a wide range of groups, and will reveal all the problems in the existing bid file," Dotsikas said.

The group contends that construction for the Games will alter the Athens city plan, shrink the capital's precious few open spaces and force financially-strapped Greece to subsidise an event that will only profit construction firms.

"It is not unusual to have different views and the committee is open to any proposals," it said in a statement. "But these views are not based on the scientific facts the committee has put to various organisations and made available to the public."
A sprawling city of four million people, Athens was incensed that the centennial 1996 Games went to Atlanta and not the ancient birthplace of the Olympics.
It vowed never to bid again but soon changed its mind and decided to go for the 2004 Games by projecting an image of a modern city with state of the art facilities.
Work on a new $2.5 billion Athens international airport and $2.1 billion Athens subway system is scheduled to be completed by 2001. Athens already has an 80,000-seat Olympic Stadium.

But new motorways, an Olympic village at the foot of Mount Parnes north of Athens, a group of sports facilities at the Faliron coastal zone and a 3.5 km (two mile) long yachting centre are still to be built.

Environmentalists have already slammed the choice of venue for rowing and canoeing at what they say is a sensitive bird habitat at Skinias, north-east of Athens, forcing the committee to alter its plans.
"The bidding committee, understanding the importance of protecting the Skinias marine habitat, has designed a new orientation for the venue," the committee said in a statement.

Athens is considered among the top favourites along with Cape Town, Stockholm and Rome. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) will short-list four or five cities in March, before making their final choice in September.
